metadata.title: 4 Interesting Articles Data Scientists Should Read This Week (Nov 13) | by Richmond Alake | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: 4 Interesting Articles Data Scientists Should Read This Week (Nov 13)
metadata.description: The book referred to in Bernardo’s article is titled “The Master Algorithm”, a luring title for most machine learning practitioners. Bernardo proposes that there are several ambiguous statements…

all_paragraphs: Bernardo provides a review of a book that offers a non-technical perspective of the field of machine learning and associated topics.
The book referred to in Bernardo’s article is titled “The Master Algorithm”, a luring title for most machine learning practitioners.

Bernardo proposes that there are several ambiguous statements, promises and questions surrounding Artificial Intelligence, but his general efforts are directed towards the desire to seek more knowledge.

The review of the “The Master Algorithm” by Bernardo is detailed and direct, as it summarises the surrounding topics and concerns of the ten chapters in the book, and provides a personal opinion from Bernardo on the intention of the book’s author and the aspects that the book is somewhat lacking in.

Perhaps you are a data scientist that needs a break from Jupyter notebooks, endless tutorial blogs and dark screen, then “The Master Algorithm” might be that breath of fresh air you require that doesn’t stray too far from the realms of AI.
Read Bernardo’s review and find out more.
The integration of various forms of AI technologies within plain sight of human society has typically been controversial.

The controversy stems from the constant monitoring by government governing bodies that invades the privacy of unsuspecting citizens. If you are still unsure as to what I’m describing as controversial AI, then think of facial recognition systems or surveillance systems equipped with AI.
Ella’s article explores the impact of the integration of AI technology within communities that are not welcoming of the high-level of privacy they have to exchange in turn for security.
Especially when the data of these systems are no longer in the hands of government governing bodies, but can also be accessed by everyday citizens.

Computer Vision and Deep learning techniques have been in instrumental in creating efficient licence plates readers at such a pace that enables ideas to become research work, and now, actual products.

Ella’s article focuses on a particular manufacturer of automatic licence plate readers, Flock Safety. The article also includes the statement and opinions of citizens that have had the tool offered by Flock Safety within their communities.
A good read for machine learning practitioners seeking to gain a high-level overview of the societal impact of the algorithms we develop.
Read this if you are a Data Scientist interested in creating machine learning model with little to no bias.
Bias within Machine Learning models has been a recent topic of discussion, especially with the increase in the adoption of AI technology such as facial recognition and tracking.
Ruben’s post on mitigating the propagation of bias from dataset to trained model is of high relevancy to Data Scientists of all levels.
Ruben introduces the key ideas of enforcing fairness within machine learning models by providing readers with a description of the term ‘Fairness modelling’.

Apart from providing several conceptual information and key terminologies associated with the topic of fairness modelling, Ruben’s article also includes the technical implementation details of enforcing fairness within a dataset.

Ruben demonstrates the utilisation of a python package developed by Microsoft called Fairlearn; the package is leveraged to measure and gauge the level of fairness within a dataset based on certain key metrics and protected variables.
For data science job applicants looking to understand role definitions within the data science field.

Data Science as a field is concerned with the involvement of different roles and disciplines. Trying to find precisely what roles best encapsulate your interests and skills in data science can be challenging, and at times confusing.
Sara’s latest article explores the definition and responsibilities of ten roles, all associated with the data science field.

You might be reading this and think that you are more than aware of all the roles associated with the data science field, but believe me, some roles and descriptions included in this article might surprise you.
Sara has written an article that a number of data science job applicants will appreciate, as it is very important that understanding what role best fit your expertise.
To connect with me or find more content similar to this article, do the following:
